Research Interests:

I am an experimental particle physicist, and I use particle collider to study elementary particles and their interactions. Since 2008, I have been a member of the ATLAS collaboration at CERN's Large Hadron Collider (LHC), which discovered the Higgs boson in 2012 together with the CMS collaboration. My broad research interests include study of the Higgs boson, search for physics beyond the Standard Model, and detector R & D. For the next few years, I plan to work on the following projects in particular:

  • Discover and measure the not yet observed the Higgs production in association with top quarks
  • Search for physics beyond the Standard Model in final states of jets and/or long-lived particles
  • Detector upgrades for the High Luminosity LHC program

Discovery of the Higgs boson at CERN's Large Hadron Collider

The discovery of the Higgs boson was a culmination of 40 years theoretical and experimental particle physics endeavors. I contributed to the discovery of the Higgs boson [1] through my Ph.D. thesis work on the search and discovery of the Higgs boson in the diphoton final state using the ATLAS detector at the LHC. I worked on various aspects of the analysis of diphoton data, and in particular, I developed a framework that performs likelihood fits of the diphoton mass distributions in order to evaluate the statistical significance of the observed excess. I also developed a method to test different spin hypotheses of the then newly discovered Higgs boson in the diphoton final state [2].

The picture on the right was taken in midnight June 24, 2012, 10 days before the announcement of the Higgs boson discovery. It was the day when all data were processed and an excess of 4.5 sigma in the diphoton channel was seen.

Midnight June 24, 2012

Meausring the Properties of the Higgs boson

The production of Higgs boson in association with top quarks (ttH) is one of the main production modes of the Higgs boson that are not yet observed. The observation of this process will be the next milestone in the study of the Higgs boson as it will be the first direct evidence of the top Higgs Yukawa coupling. Measuring the ttH production not only will provide a model-independent determination of the top Yukawa coupling, but also will be sensitive to potential effects of BSM physics. I have been focused on the diphoton channel. Recently, I developed a machine learning based method that significantly improved the experimental sensitivity of the ATLAS experiment to the ttH process in the diphoton channel[4]. I currently work on the further refinement of this method and the analysis of latest LHC data, in order to observe the ttH process. Once the observation is established, I plan to use the ttH events to probe potential new physics.

Search for Physics beyond the Standard Model

The Large Hadron Collider is a discovery machine, and I am always excited by the opportunity of discovering something that may fundamentally change our understanding of the Laws of Nature. In the LHC Run-1, I have been involved in a number of new physics searches using events of photons. Lately, I have focused my search effort on the multijet final state, which has long been considered as one of the most challenging places to look for new physics.

At the beginning of the LHC Run-2, I led a search for TeV-scale black hole production at the Large Hadron Collider [5]. This search set the most stringent limit on the production of black hole at the Large Hadron Collider. Recently, I have been working on a search for massive supersymmetric particles decaying to many jets via R-parity violating couplings [6].

Detector R&D for future colliders

A High Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC) run is planned to take place in 2026. This program is expected to collect approximately 3000 fb-1 data after ten years running. This data set allows us to measure the properties of the Higgs boson at an unprecedented precision and to explore a much larger phase space for BSM physics.

I have worked on the R&D for the upgrade of the ATLAS Inner Tracker (ITk) for the upcoming HL-LHC run. This includes studying properties of the mechanical support structure, testing electrical components of the protyping detectors, exploring new hardware based track seeded trigger [8], as well as simulation study of the tracking performance [9,10].

I look forward to continuing my contribution to the Phase-2 upgrade efforts that enable the LHC experiments to fully exploit the physics opportunities brought about by the HL-LHC program. In a longer term, I am also interested in conducting R&D for detector technologies needed for future hadron and/or lepton colliders.

Search, Explore, and Observe Natural Wonders on Earth

Otherwise in life, I enjoy outdoor life, exploring natural wonders by hiking, driving, and camping!
